content.description:
E4 6c+

Straight out of Scotland,

Two-Bit Grit

transcends time, landing you in Yorkshire's

Peak District

. While you're not climbing gritstone or shale, placements between bolts are shaky, sparse, and don't exactly inspire

going for it

.

To begin, find some bloke and get a good spot, actually- make sure you get a great spot then proceed to boulder the start (the

Wasatch Guide

notes the crack on the right as being off, not that it helps).  Crimp on a slab-- over nothing-- passing the first bolt to a "rest" at an undercling; fiddle with some small pieces of gear then carry on remembering to breathe. From here move up and left over sketchy territory making sure not to skip any opportunities to place anything! Heading up and slightly left pull off some delicate moves to gain a solid stance. From this point, eye up the head wall, commit to a few awkward moves, and grab a

thank-you

hold. Clip the last bolt and fire the bouldery top out. A mini-epic~!
content.protection:
A semi-automatic

Johnny Dawes

rope gun, pink and yellow lycra capris,  two draws, slings, and gear up to an inch and a half.
content.location:
Right of

The Angry Inch

sits a clean bulging face. Here starts

Two-Bit Grit

.

content.description: Start with some committing slab moves to get to a flake then follow the cracks/flakes to the notch in the roof. Go up the notch and the anchors are on the right.  This is a good warm up for f/8.
content.protection: single set of Cams 1/2 inch to 2 inch.  Bolts and Rap rings for anchors.

content.description: Climb cracks and weaknesses over a small roof to the first bolt.  Use a small pocket to get up to the second bolt over the roof.  The rock is flaky and makes pulling the roof a true challenge.  Climb under the tree and enjoy better climbing above on a nice crystal-filled face.  This route would be a good candidate for anchor chains.  With some cleaning up, this route will earn more stars.  The view from the top is terrific.  Bring your camera and set your aperture accordingly!
content.protection: 5 bolts and a red Metolius for the flake before the first bolt.
content.location: Around the corner and down (West) from Draw the Line (about 50 feet).  Look up high for the bolts.  There are no anchors, so walk off to the northwest.

content.description: The right most of the 2 bolted lines on the left face.  Short, frictiony, and 1 tough move.  Downclimb through the gully on the right.
content.protection: 2 draws for the route, and some large slings for the anchors.  A bit of natural gear wouldn't hurt for the anchors, but if I remember, you have flakes, boulders and trees.

climbs.name: Draw the Line
climbs.fa: H. Armantrout, B. Cramer, D. Casey, 1983

content.description: The left line on the left face.  Again short, frictiony with 1 tough move.  Downclimb at the gully on the right.
content.protection: Large slings will get you the anchors on the ledge using Large boulders, flakes, and trees. Possibly could use other gear.  2 draws for the climb.

climbs.name: The Angry Inch
climbs.fa: T. Phillips, L. Douglas, T. Anderson 5/08/08

content.description: This is a bouldery little route. Precision feet and sequence are required to make it to the top. Cool underclings and high step thrown in for good measure are memorable. You can escape out right near the top, or hang in there and go straight up (contrived but fun).
content.protection:
6 QD's (including anchor) and a #3 metolius.

Descend from chain anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route lies to the left of

Two Bit Grit

and right of the 5.9 slab routes.
